newsitem.title: UK: Spike in IPAI data attributed to new data - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Spike in IPAI data attributed to new data - analysts.

text.p: The sharp rise in IPAI aluminium output figures on Thursday was almost entirely due to the inclusion of fresh data from China, Tajikistan and Montenegro, some metals analysts said.
But the new data were unexpected and left some questions about crucial Chinese output unanswered, said others.

The International Primary Aluminium Institute released provisional figures showing that daily average primary aluminium output in January rose to 57,600 tonnes compared with 51,900 tonnes in December.
The IPAI said that for the first time data from China and Tajikistan were included in the Asian category, while data from Montenegro was classed with East/Central Europe figures

"There is nothing to get excited about. The jump in the IPAI figures from December to January seems entirely attributable to the inclusion of the new figures," said analyst Anthony Bird of Anthony Bird Associates.
"It seems there has been no change in the underlying figures," he added.
He based his opinion on IPAI's December and January figures for other regions as well as previous production data on China, Tajikistan and Montenegro from alternative sources.
But analyst Angus MacMillan of brokers Billiton said the absence of historic data to indicate Chinese output in previous months was confusing.
"All they are doing is muddying the waters," MacMillan said.
